extractions.description: The paper investigates the ability of transformers to simulate the functions of weighted finite automata (WFAs) and weighted tree automata (WTAs). The theoretical findings are supported by experimental results showing that transformers can be trained to simulate more complex automata such as WFAs and WTAs efficiently.

title.value: Simulating Weighted Automata over Sequences and Trees with Transformers
title.justification: The title is clearly stated on the first page of the paper and matches the context of the given content.
title.quote: Simulating Weighted Automata over Sequences and Trees with Transformers

type.justification: The paper focuses on proving that transformers can simulate WFAs and WTAs and provides theoretical bounds and formal proofs for its claims.
type.quote: We show that transformers can simulate both WFAs as well as WTAs, and that they can do so compactly.

research_field.justification: The paper discusses the context of transformers, which are prominent models in Natural Language Processing and their ability to simulate automata.
research_field.quote: Transformers are ubiquitous models in the natural language processing (NLP) community and have shown impressive empirical successes in the past few years.

sub_research_field.justification: The paper deals with the formal computational capabilities of transformers in relation to finite automata and weighted tree automata, which are topics under formal language theory.
sub_research_field.quote: In this work, we show that transformers can simulate weighted finite automata (WFAs), a class of models which subsumes DFAs, as well as weighted tree automata (WTA), a generalization of weighted automata to tree structured inputs.

name.justification: The paper evaluates the performance of transformers in simulating WFAs and WTAs, which is a central focus of the research.
name.quote: In this work, we show that transformers can simulate weighted finite automata (WFAs), a class of models which subsumes DFAs, as well as weighted tree automata (WTA), a generalization of weighted automata to tree structured inputs.

name.justification: The experiments section of the paper mentions training transformers using synthetic data to show that logarithmic solutions can be found for the simulation tasks.
name.quote: To do so, we train transformers on simulation tasks using synthetic data.

name.justification: The Pautomac dataset is explicitly mentioned as being used to evaluate the performance of transformers in simulating WFAs.
name.quote: We evaluate models on target WFAs taken from the Pautomac dataset (Verwer et al., 2014).

name.justification: The PyTorch framework is explicitly mentioned as being used for the implementation of the transformer models for the experiments.
name.quote: For all experiments, we use the PyTorch TransformerEncoder implementation and use a model with 2 attention heads.
